message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing urinary retention, and among the options, only Prazosin, an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor blocker, can help in relieving the retention by relaxing the internal urethral sphincter. Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that helps in bladder emptying in certain conditions but not in this case. Phenylephrine is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor agonist, which will worsen the retention. Bethanechol is a cholinergic agonist that will stimulate bladder contraction but not help in the patient's case with the simultaneous contraction of the internal urethral sphincter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and urodynamic studies suggest neurogenic bladder. Prazosin is an alpha-adrenergic blocker that can relax the internal urethral sphincter and improve urinary symptoms. Neostigmine, Phenylephrine, and Bethanechol all affect smooth muscle contraction and are not appropriate for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing urinary retention and the simultaneous contractions of the detrusor muscle and the internal urethral sphincter, suggesting a neurogenic cause. Prazosin, an alpha-adrenergic blocker, is used to relax the urethral sphincter and improve urinary flow in this situation. The other options are not appropriate for neurogenic urinary retention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest neurogenic bladder, and prazosin is an alpha-1 blocker that can help reduce bladder outlet resistance and improve voiding. Neostigmine is used to treat myasthenia gravis, while phenylephrine and bethanechol are used to treat urinary retention caused by sphincter dysfunction and detrusor muscle underactivity, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s urinary symptoms suggest neurogenic bladder, which is commonly treated with alpha-blockers such as Prazosin to increase bladder capacity and reduce intravesical pressure. Neostigmine, Phenylephrine, and Bethanechol are not commonly used for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing neurogenic bladder, which is a common complication of spinal cord injury. Prazosin is an alpha-blocker and can help relax the internal urethral sphincter to improve urinary flow. Neostigmine is a cholineresterase inhibitor that can increase bladder contractility, but this is not the problem in this patient. Bethanechol is a muscarinic receptor agonist that can increase bladder contractility, but this is not the problem in this patient. Phenylephrine is a alpha-agonist and can help with urinary retention, but this is not the problem in this patient since the bladder is overactive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has urinary retention due to spinal cord injury, and Prazosin can be used to relax the smooth muscles in the bladder neck and prostate to help with voiding. Neostigmine and bethanechol are used to increase contraction of the detrusor muscle, which is already contracting in this case. Phenylephrine is used to treat hypotension and is not indicated here.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of neurogenic bladder, which is a common complication of traumatic spinal cord injury. Prazosin is an alpha-adrenergic blocker that can be used to relax smooth muscle and improve bladder emptying in patients with neurogenic bladder. The other options do not target this specific issue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing urinary retention, and the urodynamic studies suggest neurogenic bladder. Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist that can help improve bladder emptying in cases of neurogenic bladder. Neostigmine and bethanechol are cholinergic agents that can increase bladder contraction, but they are not appropriate for this patient's symptoms. Phenylephrine is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor agonist and can cause further urinary retention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest neurogenic bladder, which can be treated with alpha-adrenergic blockers such as prazosin to relax the internal urethral sphincter and improve urine flow. Neostigmine and bethanechol stimulate bladder contraction, which could worsen the patient's symptoms. Phenylephrine is an alpha-agonist that could worsen the patient's symptoms by further constricting the urethra.
